title: Welcome to the Workshop
text:
Frequently Asked Questions

How do I access the workshop materials?
All materials are freely available online.



Who is hosting the workshop?
This workshop has been organized in collaboration with Terkko Health Hub and EstiMates.









What kind of services does EstiMates provide?
EstiMates offers a range of services such as:

Statistical consulting:

Statistical Leadership & Planning
Statistical Reporting & Programming

Clinical Study Data Management
Data Science

Find more about EstiMates from our website.


Data Credit
The results and data shown in this work have been published by Liikkanen et al. in:
Body movement as a digital biomarker in chronic pain rehabilitation: a real-world pilot study using virtual reality, Frontiers in Virtual Reality, 6, 1601823 (2025).
The original results are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) license.

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Background on Chronic Pain

Chronic pain is defined as pain that persists or recurs for 3 months or longer
In 2020, approximately 619 million people globally were affected by low back pain
Low back pain and neck pain have constantly been one of the leading causes of disability worldwide (Measuring with years lived with disability)
The current gold standard for diagnosing chronic pain is patient self-report
Traditional medical interventions include methods such as spinal injections, surgery, and pharmacological interventions

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Virtual Reality for Rehabilitation

Non-pharmacological interventions include physical therapy, exercise, and cognitive behavioral therapy
Virtual Reality (VR) has been proposed as a (supplementary) tool for rehabilitation and pain management
Several studies conducted under controlled trial settings have shown promising results, such as reduced pain intensity and reduced kinesiophobia (movevement-related fear of pain)

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
VR Rehabilitation
Study participants were given the opportunity to use a Virtual Reality (VR) headset on their own time for rehabilitation exercises.

Participants took part in a study with a tentative length of 12 weeks (not mandated)
The participants were instructed to use the VR environment freely to mimic real world usage
Movement data were collected using Meta Oculus Quest 2 VR equipment (e.g.Â \(x,y,z\) -coordinates of headset and hand controllers) at approximately 30 ms intervals

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Dealing with Real-World Data

Monte Carlo SimulationWhy and How?






Real-world data is often messy and incomplete
Monte Carlo simulation can be used to assess the robustness of the results
Normalize picking speed to span values from 0 to 1
Pick 4 random participants for each round
Take bootstrap sample of 1001 observations from pooled data and fit regression line (Repeat 3000 rounds)

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Speed Improvement


Monte Carlo estimates of movement speed improvement for a hypothetical subject with average speeds ranging from 0.15 m/s to 1.1 m/s.

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Not Really

Issues with data
VR platform rights were sold during the study which complicated funding
Study plan complicated interpretation of results







Tip of the Day


Consult a statistician when designing a study, and talk to data professionals when planning data collection.

title: Chronic Pain Rehabilitation and Real World Data
text:
Conclusions

Virtual Reality (VR) can effectively supplement chronic pain rehabilitation, with studies showing improvements in movement speed and reduced kinesiophobia.
RWD is inherently messy and requires exploration and robust analysis methods to derive reliable insights.
Study design and data collection planning are critical â€” unexpected issues can complicate interpretation and outcomes.
